lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
In React, organizing components into their own files is a good practice.

Creating a file per component keeps our project nice and tidy.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
We need to import React from the React package in every file we use for React.

Make sure to pick import followed by React and then from, "react".

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
After we made sure to import React, we can create our functional component.

Make sure to pick const, followed by Greeting, and finally () => {}.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's return a simple h1 element to display a heading when the component is rendered.

Make sure to pick return followed by <h1> and then Hello, there!, </h1>.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To use the component elsewhere, we need to export it.

We use the default export export default Greeting to make the Greeting component available in other files.

Make sure to pick export, followed by default, and finally Greeting.

lessons.title: da
lessons.interactiveContent:
To import the component, we use import followed by its name, then the path to the file after the from keyword.

./ means the current folder in a file path. It tells the code to look for the file in the same folder as the current file.

Make sure to pick import followed by Greeting and then from, "./Greeting".

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Lastly, we can render the component in the root element.

Make sure to pick < followed by Greeting and then /, >.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Export the Message component.

Make sure to pick export followed by default and then Message, ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these is the correct way to import a React component?

import Recipe from "./Recipe"from "./Recipe" import Recipe

import Recipe from "./Recipe".

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create and export a new component called Notification and render it to display a notification.

Make sure to pick const, followed by Notification, and finally Notification.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import the component named Alert and render it to show a simple alert message.

Make sure to pick import followed by Alert and then from, "./Alert", <Alert />.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these statements about export and import in React is correct?

We use export default to export a main function from a fileReact components cannot be imported from external files

We use export default to export a main function from a file.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
So far, we've learned to create a component and display it.

Make sure to pick App, followed by <App />.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
However, we can create as many components as we want.

For example, we can create a Greeting component next to our App component. We do this in another file to keep everything nice and tidy.

Make sure to pick Greeting, followed by Greeting.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can now, use the new Greeting component inside the App component.

If we want to use a component from another file, we must import it via the import statement we already know.

Make sure to pick import followed by Greeting and then from, "./Greeting", ;.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Every component can only return one element. If we want to include the new component, we must wrap the existing JSX in an element.

Add a div element around the JSX that the component returns.

Make sure to pick <div>, followed by </div>.

lessons.title: da
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we return more than one line of JSX, we wrap the returned JSX inside parentheses.

Add a div element around the JSX that the component returns.

Make sure to pick (, followed by ).

lessons.title: da - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we return a wrapper element, like the div element, we can add as many elements as we want inside.

Add a p element below the h1 element.

Make sure to pick <p>, followed by I'm happy that you are here., and finally </p>.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
It's time to add the Greeting component. We add it like any other element.

Add the imported Greeting element to display the Greeting component inside the App component.

Make sure to pick < followed by Greeting and then /, >.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
A component is a building block, just like an element. We can add a component as often as we want.

The App component can display the Greeting component as often as we want.

Make sure to pick <Greeting />, followed by <Greeting />, and finally <Greeting />.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render the MarvelHero component twice inside the App component.

Make sure to pick < followed by MarvelHero and then /, >, <, MarvelHero, /, >.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
In a React application, how can you include a component from another file?

By using the import statementBy using the require statementBy copying and pasting the code into the same file

By using the import statement.

lessons.title: Lesson #9 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import both the Hero and the Villain components inside the App component.

Make sure to pick Hero, followed by "./Villain".

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the primary reason for creating separate files for different components in React?

To keep the code structured and maintainableTo make copying files easier

To keep the code structured and maintainable.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
When creating a React component, what is the correct way to return a single parent HTML element?

Wrap all the code in a divCreate multiple top-level elements

Wrap all the code in a div.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import the Warning React component and render it inside the App component.

Make sure to pick Warning, followed by "./Warning", and finally <Warning />.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also put multiple components into one file.

Make sure to pick const followed by Article and then =, () => {, }.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to use a component that was defined in the same file, we can use it directly.

Make sure to pick <, followed by Article, and finally />.

lessons.title: da - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Components are like the building blocks we use to build our React app, so we can use them as often as we want.

Make sure to pick <Article />, followed by <Article />, and finally <Article />.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also export multiple classes using named exports instead of a default export.

We put the export keyword in front of every component we want to export.

Make sure to pick export, followed by export.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To import multiple named exports, we list each item we want to import in curly braces.

Import the two components Article and Header from the Components file.

Make sure to pick { followed by Article, and then Header, }.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also decide to import only one of the exported components.

Import only Header from the Components file.

Make sure to pick {, followed by Header, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
How would you export both Article and Header using named exports?

Add export before each componentUse default export for both

Add export before each component.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import the components Article and Header from the Components.jsx file.

Make sure to pick import followed by { and then Article,, Header, }, from, "./Components".

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these is true about exporting components?

Named exports allow multiple exports from a single fileDefault exports allow exporting multiple items

Named exports allow multiple exports from a single file.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
If you import a component using curly braces, which type of export must have been used?

Named exportDefault export

Named export.

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we export multiple components, we can also choose to make one of the exports the default export.

Make the Header component the default export.

Make sure to pick export, followed by export, and finally default.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've already seen how to import a default exported component. We import it via the import statement and define the path to the file.

Import the Header component from the Components file.

Make sure to pick import followed by Header and then from, "./Components";.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To import a named export alongside a default exported component, we list them in curly braces and add them to the same import statement.

Alongside the Header component, import the Recipe component as a named export from the Components file.

Make sure to pick , followed by { and then Recipe, }.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can ignore the default export and import only named exports instead.

Import the Recipe component as a named export from the Components file.

Make sure to pick import followed by { Recipe } and then from, "./Components";.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which statement correctly shows how to set a default export for a component?

export default Headerexport Header default

export default Header.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use a default export statement to export the Navigation component.

Make sure to pick export followed by default and then Navigation, ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
After making the component Footer a default export, how do you correctly import it?

import Footer from "./Components"import { Footer } from "./Components"

import Footer from "./Components".

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import the Main and the Sidebar components. Check the Component.jsx file to see which one should be exported in which way.

Make sure to pick Main, followed by Sidebar.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import only the named export Badge from the Components.jsx file.

Make sure to pick import followed by { and then Badge, }, from, "./Components", ;.
